title: Why do champions like Shen and Singed still have no scaling MR?
body: I can ALMOST understand Singed with his ult, but what's the excuse for Shen? Even Galio has scaling MR... I don't get it.

Her health pool is not halved to compensate, and she in fact only pays about 50-150 HP as a 'cost' for this, which is stupidly minor for a GA-effect.

{{champion:22}} has very middle-of-the-road AD at level 1 and while her lvl 18 AD is bottom-barrel, that's by literally .5 AD compared to the next people on the list.  Methinks thou dost protest too much.

{{champion:268}} was something incredibly new, and Riot was conservative with certain stats in order to make sure he wasn't OP on launch.  He was actually a bit OP anyway, but they decided making his AS more normal was a reasonable compensation buff for the heavy nerfs he took.  Also, if you're ignoring kit steroids, he's got better scaling AS than {{champion:222}} , ironic, no?

{{champion:432}} He's very experimental, expect him to be wonky.  I like that Riot is willing to do that with new champions.

For Sion, you have to keep one thing in mind: Sion's lower base health is there to better distinguish between the the low case, average case and high case. To get comparable numbers as your out-of-the-mill tank, he just needs around 10 CS per level, with one of the 10 ideally being a Cannon. Also, remember that these figures do not include kills and assists, which each are worth 10 HP, too (like big minions and monsters).

Low case, aka you deny him all game and he just cannot farm W stacks aka <10 CS/lvl and no kills: Sion will have lower health than comparable bruisers if he is behind and indeed punished for his health stacking passive. However, this is intended as a reward for you properly playing against a limitlessly healthstacking .
Average case, aka around 10 CS/lvl: Sion's tankiness is comparable to most other tanks in the game (93 to 101 HP/level).
High case, way more than 10 CS/lvl: Raidboss time.

In Riot-land, champions are nerfed and buffed according to their strengths and weaknesses, to form a good game.  Sometimes this results in things that, when taken out of context, sound funny, but when the context is provided, make sense.

To look at Diana specifically, chamions with lower non-kit AS than Diana include(not inclusive, but meant to make a point):

Azir, Syndra, Cho'Gath, Lulu(equal, but I'm calling it out here), Leblanc, Jinx, and Skarner.

Corki has an additional .85% AS on Diana, but lacks a kit steroid, making Diana come out 19.15% AS ahead of Corki before items.

Basically, Diana doesn't have an abysmal base AS, she has a reasonably normal one that's on the low end of the spectrum compared to the full champion pool, but more middle-to-high end of the spectrum when only compared to things she should be compared against.  And then she has an AS passive to boot that puts her at a higher lvl 1 total AS than almost everyone.

Basically, in Riot-land, things make sense.

just spreading knowledge, no need for bows, tell your friends too! So many people have misconception about how armor actually works.
There are no diminishing returns for Armor and MR. That is a myth. Every point of Armor/MR makes your HP 1% more effective.

Hem hem.
1% of what you see on your hp bar, not of the total counting what you already added that way. Each time you add one point, there's more difference between the two and as such the next one will be less efficient.
Let's add 100 armor each time.
Date A: 1000 visualized hp, 0 armor. 1000 actual hp for physical damage = 100% of your visualized hp (100+0 from armor).
Date B: 1000 visualized hp, 100 armor. 2000 actual hp for physical damage = 200% of your visualized hp (100+100 from armor) = 200% of your actual hp for physical damage at date A.
Date C: 1000 visualized hp, 200 armor. 3000 actual hp for physical damage = 300% of your visualized hp = 150% of your actual hp for physical damage at date B.
Date D: 1000 visualized hp, 300 armor. 4000 actual hp for physical damage = 300% of your visualized hp = 133% of your actual hp for physical damage at date C.

As you can see, each point of resistance grants you 1% of your visualised HP, but not 1% of your actual HP for that type of damage. The more you buy, the less you gain compared to what you already have.
Thus, resistance reduction/penetration of ANY kind except pure damage amplification is more efficient against people with low resistances since the lower points of resistance represent a bigger percentage of their actual health for that type of damage.

The first 100 armor grant you 50% damage reduction. If there were no diminishing returns, the second 100 armor would also give you 50% damage reduction for a total of 100% damage reduction. But no, each percentual point scales multiplicatively with the previous one. You can't get to 100% damage reduction. To reduce incoming damage by a same percentage of the current value (not only of the original one) over and over, you must buy each time more armor.

Soory, but this is just untrue. Of cause, if you compare it in %, you see less. But the actual effective HP increase by the same amount for every point of armor.

If you add 2+2 you increase by 100%.
If you add 4+2 you increase by 50%.
If you add 6+2 you increase by 33%.

That is just how percentages work, but the added value is the same every time.

Exactly what I said. You gain each time the same flat value, which is each time a lower percent of what you already have. Thus, it gets less effective. Thus, reducing low points of resistances is more important than reducing high points. Resistance reduction hurts squishies, not tanks.

No it does NOT get less effective. It is linear scaling. If you have one apple and get another one, you will have 100% more apples. If you get a third one, you will have 50% more apples. So you want to tell me that the thrird apple is worth less than the second one? Of cause not, they are both one apple. That is basic math. Percentage increase does not represent the actual increase. Galio got scaling MR when the first nerfs to Athene's went through. He was given them because he was already in a fairly weak state and was more nerfed by the changes than anyone else.

Singed has no scaling MR because
a) He has extra stats on his ultimate
b) His passive gives him extra health.

While these should benefit him they should do so in a way that is fair for his magic damage dealing opponents. As I understand it, given that magic damage is typically lower over time than physical damage and higher in burst. Magic resist is therefore "better" than armour in that each point of magic resist does more work. If you can survive the mages first blast you have a few seconds to get to them and stop them having a second. If you survive an adcs they have more and more and more coming at you.
 
The other champions that don't get MR per level are:
Kassadin, Maokai, Poppy, and Yasuo.

Notice that all of them have built into their kit some way of mitigating burst and poke either on a short cooldown or constantly. Maokai has damage reduction and regular heals, Kassading ignores a portion of MR and has a magic shield, Poppy has her passive, and Yasuo has his shield.

Singed has MR on his ultimate, regen on his ultimate and health from his passive. All mitigate burst and poke. 
Shen has near constant healing from his Q and a fairly spammable self shield. These heavily mitigate poke.

That is my guess. This does make me wonder why Fizz gets MR/level although I suppose he reacts to it rather than just has it happen and also has it on a marginally longer cooldown.
